MemberSignature.Value: public: property bool Cancel { bool get(); void set(bool value); };
member this.Cancel : bool with get, set

Attribute.AttributeName: get: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")
set: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.summary: Gets or sets a Boolean value that indicates whether strokes should be considered a gesture.
Docs.value: if the strokes are ink; if the strokes are a gesture.

remarks.format: ## Remarks When the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas.Gesture> event occurs, the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.Cancel%2A> property depends on the first <xref:System.Windows.Ink.GestureRecognitionResult> in the collection returned by the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.GetGestureRecognitionResults%2A> method. If the value of the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.GestureRecognitionResult.ApplicationGesture%2A> property is <xref:System.Windows.Ink.ApplicationGesture.NoGesture>, or if it is a gesture whose <xref:System.Windows.Ink.GestureRecognitionResult.RecognitionConfidence%2A> is a value other than <xref:System.Windows.Ink.RecognitionConfidence.Strong>, then <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.Cancel%2A> is `true`. Otherwise, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.Cancel%2A> is `false`. When <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.Cancel%2A> is `false`, the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas> adds the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.Strokes%2A> to its <xref:System.Windows.Ink.StrokeCollection>. When <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.Cancel%2A> is `true`, the strokes are not added to the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvas>.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance class System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection`1<class System.Windows.Ink.GestureRecognitionResult> GetGestureRecognitionResults() cil managed
Public Function GetGestureRecognitionResults () As ReadOnlyCollection(Of GestureRecognitionResult)

Docs.summary: Returns results from the gesture recognizer.
Docs.returns: A collection of possible application gestures that the might be.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The collection returned by the <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.GetGestureRecognitionResults%2A> method is sorted by the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.GestureRecognitionResult.RecognitionConfidence%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property. For example, <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.GetGestureRecognitionResults%2A> might return a collection of <xref:System.Windows.Ink.GestureRecognitionResult> objects with the following values:
|Index|ApplicationGesture|RecognitionConfidence| |-----------|------------------------|---------------------------| |0|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.ApplicationGesture.Check>|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.RecognitionConfidence.Strong>| |1|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.ApplicationGesture.NoGesture>|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.RecognitionConfidence.Intermediate>| |2|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.ApplicationGesture.Curlicue>|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.RecognitionConfidence.Poor>| |3|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.ApplicationGesture.DoubleCurlicue>|<xref:System.Windows.Ink.RecognitionConfidence.Poor>|
This means that the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.GestureRecognizer> recognizes that it is very likely that the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.Stroke> is a check mark, relatively likely that the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.Stroke> in not a gesture, and not at all likely that the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.Stroke> is a curlicue or a double curlicue.
> [!NOTE] > The <xref:System.Windows.Controls.InkCanvasGestureEventArgs.GetGestureRecognitionResults%2A> method can return an array with <xref:System.Windows.Ink.ApplicationGesture.NoGesture> with a higher degree of <xref:System.Windows.Ink.RecognitionConfidence> than it has for other application gestures. This means that it is more likely that the <xref:System.Windows.Ink.Stroke> is not a gesture, as opposed to a gesture that has a lower <xref:System.Windows.Ink.RecognitionConfidence>.
